review:
ReviewBought the 2019 facelift edition, whose interior is so much better than the 2018 one. Looks much more upscale as compared to last year. More chrome, and interior lighting that's classy rather than striking. 

The A4 beats everyone in its class when u compare its price. Significantly cheaper than the C class and 3 series, considering u get a 2.0T engine. Its fuel economy/power ratio hands down leaves the japanese counterparts in the dust too, like mazda, toyota. 

The drive is very calm and composed, for a 2.0 turbocharged engine, cruising at 1200RPM constantly: explains the fuel efficiency. Sports mode is very toned down, only keeping RPM at 2000, which is very weird andl doesn't maximise the car's potential. Paddle shifters are a must to use, if you want to maximise the car's power. No worries though, as it can overtake any car in traffic in a breeze, without even hitting 3000rpm, with its 320NM powerband from 1200rpm to 4000rpm. 

The A4 is very under-provided for, for an Audi. Horrific 16 inch rims, no memory seat for a family sedan, virtual cockpit is not stock. The audi drive select is completely fake, comfort mode is redundant, no adaptive dampers or air suspensions means they can't really improve ride comfort. Dynamic mode makes the steering artificially heavy, instead of responsive with high feedback.

What I likePrice

Powertrain and comfort. 

2019 New front diffuser and fake exhaust covers (that make the car look sportier)

Fuel economy taking into context the power

Great boot space and accessibility. 

360 degree sensor, helps u prevent unnecessary scratches at ur bumpers

What I do not like19.2 Km/L fuel consumption on paper, however once changed to 18 inch rims, becomes around 11-12 when travelling urban. around 14-16 if u travel on highway clear traffic

16 inch rims (a must change when u buy it)

No memory seats

Touchscreen would be much preferred, in addition to the Audi MMI panel. 

Not the best steering that audi has provided. Its good enough, and much better than most cars, but expected more, with the steering feeling very light and little feedback at low speeds. High speeds makes the steering tighter but still not the best audi has made.

ReviewBought the 2019 minor facelift 2.0L AUDI. This is the first AUDI i own. Use to drive BMW and Mercedes in the past. In terms of power, i personally feels that it has the oomph in it. Engine feels more responsive and powerful. Overtaking other vehicles seem like a breeze in the park.

What I like- Virtual Cockpit 
- Handling
- Engine power and responsiveness
- Quiet and smooth ride
- Minor change to rear exhuast pipe to keep with current time.

What I do not like- Lack of memory seat
- 16" Alloy rim, makes the tyres look like big balloons.
- Auto Start/Stop that has to be turn off manually each time. And the fact that it is located next to traction control button, cause me to press the wrong one a couple of times.

ReviewPros: 
VC is really a game changer
Good quality interior and comfortable 
2.0T really gives you the boost when you need it
Handsome car that is not overly flashy
All-around good car

Cons: 
No Audi connect - this is a very good feature and I cannot comprehend why SG doesn’T have this. 
No memory seats! Don’T understand why they can make this standard. 
Slightly too high, can be lowered 
No electronic tailgate, 
16in rims that come as standard really don’T flatter the car
Auto start-stop cannot be turned off by default

ReviewPros: 
VC is really a game changer
Good quality interior and comfortable 
2.0T really gives you the boost when you need it
Handsome car that is not overly flashy
All-around good car

Cons: 
No Audi connect - this is a very good feature and I cannot comprehend why SG doesn’T have this. 
No memory seats! Don’T understand why they can make this standard. 
Slightly too high, can be lowered

16in rims that come as standard really don’T flatter the car

ReviewGood price for the power it delivers. Disappointing as it does not include memory seats at the front.

What I likeThe power it delivers.
The interior is cosy.
The gadgets including the VC is interesting.
Back row has air conditioning.

What I do not likeThe centre piece at back row is too high.
Driving position is a bit Low coming from an SUV driver previously.

ReviewComing from Volvo, this 2L car has a 10km/L consumption compare to my 2L Volvo which is only getting 8km/L. Although on paper is is about 200BHP, its pickup is comparable to Volvo probably because Volvo is heavier

I like the way the gear stick is design for you to rest your hand and the buttons to navigate the user interface.

The Virtual Cockpit is nice, good for finding your way by having a top view of the area so that i can divert out of traffic jam easily

What I like- fuel consumption
- power
- Virtual Cockpit

What I do not like- keyless entry sometime required many press to lock/unlock
- cannot permanent disable start/stop engine (as with most Conti car)

ReviewHave driven this 1.4 car for 10,000km before giving up to another car. Generally, the car is on par with camry if you will to compete on comfort level. Due to the high suspension, driver will need to pay extra precaution when driving in high speed. Car will tend to drift left and right. Auto tilt down mirror when put on reverse gear did not work well as the angle was not tilt to max low where you can see the parking white line. The rear will tend to skid away when perform U-turn, not sure if this is factory design issue. Have send to premium for check but no defect found. Sold it away due to safety reason.

ReviewDecided on the A3 as my first car due to its price point. Got it at 110K at suntec roadshow in July. Have clocked 1000KM and liking it so far, especially the fuel consumption. I really liked the colour combination of dark blue exterior with dark brown leather seats. I was given the apple carplay option but didnt want it as i honestly don't think its that useful. Ive tried it on other Jap car and sometimes it doesnt even charge the phone. I can just connect to the audio using bluetooth which is good enough for me.

What I likeFuel consumption
Dynamic running lights
Size
Decent build quality
responsive engine

What I do not likestart stop system
no audi logo on engine
wind noise at high speed
stock 16inch rims

ReviewFor a 1.0 L engine, the power output is consider good and should have no issue with normal city drive. 

However, it does feel a little out of breath when going incline at expressway.

Steering is light, a little too light for my liking even when switch to dynamic.

What I likeDecent build quality
Nice driving experience 
Value for money when comparing to its rivals
Comfortable
Simple and elegant interior

What I do not likeSteering feels too light for me
Optional upgrades may be required (reverse camera, Apple carplay, wheels, etc)
Wished the 1.4 L engine option is still available

ReviewI've been driving my A3 for about 1.5mths. Collect it at the end of Jan. I bought the A3 during the motor show event earlier this year. I love the look, drive and feel of this car. However, this car doesn't come with some of the basic features that you'll find in a Japanese make. No USB in ports in the car, No apple CarPlay. As previously mentioned, the MMI navigation + Smartphone Interface feature is an option that you'll have to indent the car for. You'll need to pay the additional for the car and indenting would involve a 3mths wait for the car, vs, collecting the car in 2 weeks.

Other than the lack of things, I love the look, drive and feel of the car so far.â€¨

What I like- 1.0 turbocharged engine translates to cheaper road tax
â€¨- Keyless entry/start/stopâ€¨- Folding mirrorsâ€¨
- Bluetooth telephone + Audio Music streaming 
â€¨- rear aircon vents

What I do not like- No USB input/outputâ€¨- No Apple Carplayâ€¨
- Costly upgrade to Sat Nav and Smartphone Interface and the long wait for it
â€¨- Start/stop system. Very unrefined and I would usually just turn it off every time I start the car.

ReviewI bought the A3 sedan during the Audi Online Sale event last month. The car does not come with the MMI navigation + Smartphone Interface feature. This was a $4000 option. In other words, plain vanilla.

The exterior styling of the car, in my opinion, is the most handsome when compared to the BMW 1 series of the MB A-class. It has the kind of executive look to it.

The interior design is simple but it definitely doesn't look cheap! Audi has definitely found the balance by designing the cabin in such a way that it has to be functional but without being too over the top (read: Saab). Like the old 'iPod', the knob right behind the gear lever makes navigating on the media console a breeze.

The Audi Drive Select function looks like a cool feature to be had. It makes the driver feel like in control of your vehicle as if you were in a true-blue sports car. However, after trying out all the different modes from Auto to Dynamic, I am convinced that this feature is nothing more than just a pun to make the car stands out from their competitors. Either that or my senses refuse to react to the competency of a 1.0 turbocharged car. Nevertheless, despite the very obvious turbo-lag at stop, the engine has enough oomph to overtake at cruising speed and more than enough to win (most) short sprint to your next traffic light.

Paying a premium price for this car, you would expect a lot from it. However, the definition of 'a lot' can be conflicting to different people. And this is quite true for Audi. You get a lot of the hard product... Like the badge 0000, the driving dynamics, German engineering, etc. The soft product like the Sat Nav, Apple Car Play, USB PORTS (YES! USB PORTS ARE NON-EXISTENT), Solar Film, Car Mats, In-car recording camera, reverse camera, servicing package, the list goes on.... Are EXCLUSIVE AND OPTIONAL. The price adds up quickly when you add what could be found as a standard in most cars but not for Audi.

What I like- Solid chasis
- 1.0 turbocharged engine translates to cheaper road tax
- Keyless entry/start/stop
- Folding mirrors
- Bluetooth telephone + Audio Music streaming (Spotify)
- rear aircon vents
- iPod-like knob
- steering wheel controls 
- paddle shifters

What I do not like** Missing
- quick release boot from inside the cabin
- No USB input/output
- Space saver spare tire

** Archaic Mulitmedia Interface
- No Apple Carplay / AA
- Costly upgrade to Sat Nav and Smartphone Interface (Carplay)
- No USB inputs

** Annoying
- Start/stop
- Small centre console box
- (very) high rear transmission tunnel 'hump'

- single tailpipe
ReviewThe 1.0T car is quiet, with a solid chasis, nice handling while FC is good. It's a car that you drive daily but wouldn't get sick of it quickly.

What I likeQuiet
Still maintain multimedia system after engine off. Multimedia will shut-down when door is open
Sharp handling
Drive mode selection - dynamic is very good yet gives pretty good FC of 12 km/l with a heavy foot
Overtaking is a breeze!
Virtual cockpit is awesome! Of course, the pricing is steep for this add-on as well
LED signal lights are very nice
Comes with sport pedals
Brake is good
Rear aircon

What I do not likeMultimedia unit does not have USB
Audi app does not have much features
Legroom wanting
No side holders at the passengers area
Only driver seat is electrically controlled
Only front doors can trigger keyless entry
Stock 16" rims :(
Start and stop has significant delay
Suspension is good but wear pretty fast
Not very sporty looking. Some "enhancements" to be done haha

ReviewBought my white Audi Q2 1.4 turbo TFSI engine last month and it appeared to be one of the best decisions I've made. Traded in my 5 year old BMW 5 series for this and to be very honest, I was initially concerned with the space. I owned a Mini Cooper and 3 series before this. The Q2 of course cannot be compared to the cabin space of a 5 series. But I wanted something fun and zippy to drive. Something with power that looks great on the road and at the same time fun to drive without being a fuel guzzler. Reviewing this from my experience, I'd say the Q2 has the best of both worlds of both the trendiness of the Mini Cooper and the moderness and style of an Audi. It's simply the most fun car I've driven! Superb handling on the roads. Interior cabin is kept simple so if you're looking for something techy and elaborate then you might consider the highest end model. Fuel economy is one to beat. This week I drove 179km on just one bar (out of 8 bars) of petrol. Full tank about $90. 

Love the exterior daytime headlights as well as the interior mood lighting that allows you to play with lights (just like my old mini). Not to mention the fantastic sound system made by B&O. Fits 4 comfortably. 5 would be a squeeze. Good enough for me if you're mostly a solo driver like me. 

All in all, if you're looking for a stylish yet fun car from a renowned brand that ticks all the right boxes and will not burn a huge hole in your pocket, the Q2 is the one for you.

What I likeGreat look externally and internally 
Powerful engine that packs in all the punches 
Smooth right 
Really fun to drive 
Superb fuel economy 
Feels solid
Great handling 
Quiet even at 120km/h

What I do not likeSome models do not come with USB jacks and GPS
Suspension is slightly on the hard side 
Screen is a tad small

ReviewReally like this stylish car as its sportback profile sets it apart from the rest of the SUVs/MPVs/sedans

During the test drive, felt that the engine and gearbox was really smooth and acceleration from stop is a breeze.  The interior is the typical high quality Audi fare (ie. A4 and above) and makes me feel special in the driver seat

Cabin is also very well insulated as I hardly hear any noise on the move. 

Car is practical too as the boot opens up with the rear glass which gives easy access.

What I like- Stylish looks
- Premium interior quality
- Pickup and acceleration
- Comfort and quiet on the move
- Virtual cockpit
- Wide opening boot

ReviewTest driven this new A6 last weekend. Must say it's Astonishing indeed. 

First looks is the impressive lights at the front and rear as well as the curves of its new design body, though you may have to look carefully to notice the curves. 

Inside is a brand new interior compared to the previous generation where no more budge out ugly screens, making it look odd looking. Now is all totally flushed in console, making it a luxury feel in it. Great mind thoughts finally. 

The gadgets are great to have in all like the virtual 360 degree revolving camera, enhanced virtual cockpit, full touch screen console with handwriting recognition capability, and much more to your astonishment. 

A pity that no variant comes with panaromic sunroof where you need to pay as option. 

The drive is great as it comes with more power, less drag, 7 speed wet clutch gearbox (not the problematic dry clutch), more horses too. 

Gearshifts are a Breeze and power delivery is certainly better than its predecessor, and in stoppages is not jerked at. Is a gradual stop with almost to no feel of it. Has heads up display too.

Passenger at the back does experience a comfort feel as during my test drive, an Uncle followed too and too comfortable drive, even at dynamic mode, he almost fell asleep.

Only thing didn't ask if it comes with any park assist or so to try on. 

Overall, it's an improved A6 if you see it and for its drive, gadgets and best of all, its new refined interior with all nicely flushed in, thus giving it a high end luxury feeling.

It's kinda worth considering if you have a deep pocket of $240k (as of 9 September 2019).

What I likeNewly flushed in interior 
Powerful drive than it's predecessor

ReviewGot my new car 26 December 2014 from Premium Auto. It's been three months, so far here are my findings;

1. Having driven VW/Skoda cars before, in comparison, the Audi feels much better put together, quality materials, insulation, road presence and confidence it gives.
2. Noise insulation is superb except for the tyre noise caused by the sports derivative tyres that came with the car. Perhaps it should be shod with Bridgestone Turanza series instead?
3. After doing 2500km, the 1.4 TFSI starts to feel more lively. When new from the showroom, it was a bit lazy from take off but when at speed, especially if the rpm is from 1500, the take off for overtaking is noticeable.
4. Noticed a lag below 1200 rpm or from stand still, there was a slight hesitation when you floor the pedal when you move off. In comparison to my previous Skoda Octavia 1.4 TFSI, the difference is stark (although I had a remap done which gave it 150 bhp and about 250nm of torque from 1750rpm). That skoda, you can feel the G-force pressing against you. In the A3, hardly noticeable. 
5. Fuel consumption is somewhat better than the Octavia. 12.5km/l mixed. Up to 18/19km/l on the highway, quite close to the published 20km/l.
6. Features wise, it has all the bells and whistles that one can hope for, although a navigation system would have been welcomed, it's not very expansive nowadays. I'm not really into installing after market.
7. Advice for those who wants to do a remap, all the ports have been sealed and breaking those seals would void warranty. I'd wait for the car to pass the warranty period before considering it.
8. Space wise, it a lot more spacious now with the MQB platform and longer wheelbase compared to my MK 5 Octavia. 

All in all I'm happy with the purchase and would recommend anyone who is considering it.

What I like-Solid build
-Good range of features (safety and driving aids)
-Good fuel consumption
-Comfort from the MQB platform

What I do not like- Noticeable lag from standstill
- No navigation software installed
- Should be shod with a quieter set of tyres for Ambiente trim since most purchase it as a family car.

ReviewQ3 is easy to drive. Test drove this car few months ago and noticed the ride is smooth and fast despite its small engine. Kids commented it's a "Floating" Car. We like this car but the overall package offered by audi somehow was not as competitive as BMW.

What I like1. easy to drive.
2. SUV sporty look.

What I do not like1. basic interior.
2. basic sound system and features
3. rear seat is not as spacious as other brands of same class.
4. dated design.
5. overall package not as competitive as other dealers.

ReviewThe Audi Q7 is arguably the best 7 seater premium SUV in the market now. It is comfortable and looks really good. Handling and engine performance are good too. While the car is rather large, it rides and drives like a normal car with good acceleration in Sports Mode. Reliability could be one of Audi's weaker aspects with several friends switching from Audi to Mercedes. Price is slightly high too but with Premium Automobile's warranty support, the peace of mind could be worth it.

ReviewRecently bought from AD the 3L instead of the 2L basic model because the latter is way too basic for the quoted price! However, only to realise that the more expensive 3L did not even support Apple CarPlay! I was very gutted and disappointed. I have assumed that such feature should be a standard at such price, I was so v-e-r-y wrong! Not to mention, the overall buying experience with the AD is less than satisfactory for a German premium brand.
What I likeThe overall car performance and look.

What I do not likeObviously - no CarPlay support! I love technology stuffs, that is one of reasons I have chosen Audi. But I am extremely disappointed with the MMI connect that I am getting. I don't think the issue is with Audi,............

ReviewDriven this 2x, once at Audi Sport event to try out the Quattro and the other time was driving a friend's one who bought recently.

Exterior looks with the new front grills are "FIERCE", bundled with its dynamic matrix LED lights and incorporated with a 2.0L TFSI engine than the predecessor of a drinker at 3.6L or larger one.

Interior was packed with features...From having Audi Virtual Cockpit where you can get almost any info you can think of.

The 3rd row seats have an automated feature to release and lift back, a good to have for a big car like this.

The panaromic sunroof is a good one with full glass design too.

The 3rd row seats can be a little crampy if you fit in adults.

The drive off was smooth but feels a little lag when attempted to push the engine compared to the new T5 XC 90 (with Thor lights). 

Cornering was superb with the Quattro drivetrain built-in but seems turbo kicks in pretty slow compare to the new XC 90.

Overall, its a luxury 7 seater SUV to have but if you are considering this same price but with more POWER, perhaps you can look at XC 90 instead.

What I likeMany features and gadgets
Glass sunroof
Audi Virtual Cockpit

ReviewThe Virtual Cockpit is too amazing, have never seen this before and this really excites me.

Test drove it, the interior looks as spacious as the A6 and I love the sporty front bonnet. 

Very powerful drive, you will love it at first sight and keep thinking of it thereafter.

What I like1. Virtual Cockpit.
2. Sporty and fierce exterior.
3. Very classy interior with brown leather.
4. Push button brake instead of handbrake / footbrake.
5. Google map capable.
6. Awesome boot space.
7. Sporty seat that grab your body tightly.

What I do not likeWhat I do not like
1. Slightly lower height for rear passenger seat.

ReviewNever a fan of Audi until the Virtual Cockpit called out to me (especially in a sleek Coupe)  

Test drove the 190HP model. Nice drive, very good power for daily use, light steering, ride suspension is on the sporty side but can also choose the option to upgrade to dynamic damper type for more comfort and yet still able to select sporty setting at will.

Adequately equipped with a handsome body kit, 18inch rim, Sports Seats, sporty looking steering wheel with pedal shift, MMI with navigation, Virtual Cockpit as standard (couldn't stop playing with it). Anything more is just... 'more'.  There is a long list of add-on options such as auto park, B&O system, lots of trimmings, additional safety options (something like pre-sense, rear sense, side sense), sport kit etc etc.)
